segments.text: What's he going to say, maybe we ought to tell him before he sees it.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: He saw it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How could he see it? I was the first one up he was still in bed.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: He was out here when it broke.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: When?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: About four this morning. I heard it cracking and I woke up and looked out. He was standing right here when it cracked.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What was he doing out here at four in the morning?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know. When it cracked he ran into the house and cried in the kitchen.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: So you talked to him?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No. I figured it was best to leave him alone.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: He cried hard?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I could hear him right through the floor in my room.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What was he doing out here at that hour? He's dreaming about him again, he's walking around at night.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I guess he is.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: He's getting just like after he died. What is the meaning of that?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know the meaning of it, but I know one thing mom, we've made a terrible mistake with dad.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Being dishonest with him. I mean that sort of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you mean dishonest?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You know that Larry is not coming back and I know it. Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you want to do, argue with him?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No I don't want to argue with him, but it's about time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive anymore.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Why -- why shouldn't he dream of him? Walk around, waiting for him at night I mean do we contradict him, do we say straight out that we don't have any hope anymore that we haven't had hope for years now?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You can't say that to him.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We've got to say it to him.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Can you prove it, how can you prove it?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: For God sakes it's been three years, nobody comes back after three years, that's insane.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: To you it is and to me. You can talk yourself blue in the face but there is no body and no grave so where are you?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Sit down mom; I want to talk to you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: The trouble is the god damned newspapers, every month or so a boy turns up out of nowhere, so the next one is going to be Larry.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All right. All right. Listen to me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You know why I brought Annie here don't you?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You know.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I got an idea but what's the story?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No it's not only my business.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you want me to do; you're old enough to know your own mind.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So it's all right then I'll go ahead with it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, you want to make sure that your father isn't-
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: See it isn't just my business-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'm just saying
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Sometimes you infuriate me you know that. Isn't it your business to if I tell dad and he throws a fit about it? You have such a talent for ignoring things.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I ignore what I got to ignore. The girl is Larry's girl.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: She's not Larry's girl.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: From father's point of you he isn't dead and you have no right to take his girl.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You can go on from there if you know where to go but I don't know where to go, see I don't know. So what can I do for you?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know why but every time I reach out for something that I really want, I have to pull back 'cause someone else will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time after time.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There's nothing wrong with that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: To hell with that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Have you asked Annie yet?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I wanted to get this settled first.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How do you know she'll marry you? Maybe she feels the same way your father does.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it. From her letters I think she's forgotten him.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't know, I'll find out. Then we'll trash it out with dad, right? Mom, don't avoid me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So what I'm not fast with women.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I just don't see why it has to be Annie.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Because it is.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything. I mean you haven't seen her since you went away to war it's five years.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I can't help it I know her best. I mean lived next door to her my whole life. These years when I think of a wife, I think of Annie.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What do you want, a diagram?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't want a diagram. He thinks he's coming back. Chris, you marry this girl you're pronouncing him dead.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Do you know what's going to happen to your father because I don't, see?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All right. All right. Mom.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Just give it some more thought.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I've given it three years of thought. I thought that if I waited, dad would forget about Larry and we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: If I can't do that here well, then I'll have to get out.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What the hell is this?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I'll get out. I'll get married and go live some place else, maybe New York.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What the hell is this, are you crazy?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I've been a good son too long a good sucker, I'm through with it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What about the business? What is this?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Must you be inspired?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes, I like it and hour a day. If I'm going to grub for money all day long, at least in the evening I want it beautiful.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I want a family; I want kids; I want something I can give myself to. Annie is in the middle of that. Now where do I find it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Tell me, you'd leave the business?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes, on this I would.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Then help me stay here.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: All right. But you don't want to be thinking like that 'cause otherwise what did we work for, I mean the whole thing is for you, Chris, the whole shooting match is for you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know I know mom. All right. Just help me stay here.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Just don't go thinking that way.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well, I am thinking that way.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't understand you, do I?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yea, I can see that.
segments.speaker: F
